data.title: Paris Olympics 2024 Channels Number, Apps, and Where to Watch Games Online
data.meta_description: Catch the Paris Olympics 2024 on various broadcast channels, apps, and live streaming platforms worldwide. Find out how to watch your favorite events and athletes in real-time.
data.text:
Get ready for the 2024 Summer Olympics in Paris! This highly-anticipated event will be broadcast globally across multiple platforms, including traditional TV and live-streaming services. Olympic Broadcasting Services will provide a universal feed, while local broadcasters and international partners offer additional coverage. Fans worldwide can catch their favourite events and athletes in real time on the official Olympic website, mobile apps, and social media channels.

ALSO READ| Paris Olympics 2024 India Schedule

Paris Olympics 2024 Broadcast Channel Number

Viacom18 has been appointed as the official broadcast and digital partner for the Paris 2024 Olympics in India, vowing to deliver an unparalleled and captivating viewing experience. Starting July 26, 2024, Sports18 Network will broadcast the games, while JioCinema will offer complimentary access to the coverage, ensuring widespread reach and inclusivity for Indian audiences.

Channel

Coverage

Sports18 - 1

Broadcasts in English, with options for Tamil and Telugu available.

Sports18 - 2

Focuses on delivering the Games in Hindi.

Sports18 - 3

Features a global action feed.

Indian sports fans are in for a treat, with Viacom18 set to offer an unparalleled 20 simultaneous feeds during the Paris 2024 Olympics. This extensive coverage promises to bring the excitement of the games closer to home, ensuring that viewers in India don't miss a single moment of the action. In France, Warner Bros. Discovery, through Eurosport, holds the domestic broadcasting rights for the 2024 Summer Olympics, with select events and coverage also available on free-to-air television via France Télévisions.

Meanwhile, Russia and Belarus have opted not to broadcast the Games officially, citing sanctions imposed on the two nations, which has resulted in a limited participation of around 30 athletes competing under a neutral flag. Notably, this marks the first time since 1984 that Russia has declined to purchase the broadcasting rights.
